# Draft:MiniTool Software Limited

----
}}
MiniTool Software Limited is a software development company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. It was founded in 2001 by Wei Ming., and it develops utility software focused primarily on disk management, data protection, and multimedia processing. The company's software is designed for both personal and professional use and has been distributed globally across various platforms, mainly working on Windows.
History
After working in the software industry for a few years, Wei Ming began considering the idea of starting his own business. In his spare time, he started exploring potential directions and gradually developed a plan.
In 2006, Wei registered MiniTool® and began working with others who shared an interest in disk and data management. They focused on creating utility software to help users handle storage devices, recover lost data, and perform basic system maintenance.
Early years (2003–2018)
In its early years, MiniTool focused on system utilities, including disk utility, data recovery, and backup tools:
* MiniTool Power Data Recovery (2003): Recovers lost or deleted files from various storage devices like HDD, SSD, SD cards and USB drives.
* MiniTool Partition Wizard (2009): Manages disk partitions, supports OS migration and MBR-to-GPT conversion.
* MiniTool ShadowMaker (2016): Provides backup, system recovery, disk cloning, and file sync.
Transition Phase (2019–Present)
Since 2019, MiniTool has expanded into multimedia and document software:
* MiniTool MovieMaker (2019): Basic video editor for cutting, merging, and adding effects.
* MiniTool Video Converter (2020): Converts, compresses, and records video/audio files.
* MiniTool PDF Editor (2023): Edits, converts, and annotates PDFs for various use cases.
* MiniTool System Booster (2023): Optimizes system performance by cleaning junk files and managing startups.
Branding
The name MiniTool reflects the company's vision of creating lightweight, practical software. "Mini" stands for simplicity, and "Tool" emphasizes utility.
Business Model
MiniTool attracts users with free versions of its software and generates revenue by offering advanced features through a subscription-based model.
